facts.text: Petitioner selected by Madras Public Service Commission as Lower Division Clerk under Madras Ministerial Service Rules in 1949, allotted to Revenue Department, posted in South Kanara District.
Petitioner promoted as Upper Division Clerk on April 2, 1956.

State considered petitioner for inclusion in eligibility list from 1955 onwards but not selected as not considered fit; promotion on April 2, 1956 was temporary; later reverted and then posted as temporary Upper Division Clerk.
Petitioner should have been promoted much earlier due to outstanding and meritorious service.

In August 1957, petitioner considered and included in eligibility list at Serial No. 14; list regularised on December 12, 1957 in accordance with Rules 39(e) and 35 of Madras State and Subordinate Service Rules, with effect from October 19, 1957.
Regularisation resulted in loss of benefit of service and increments according to petitioner.
Reorganisation of States under State Reorganisation Act, 1956 (XXXVII of 1956); South Kanara District except Kasaragod Taluk went to new Mysore State; petitioner allotted to it.

Government of India memorandum No. O. SRDI-1. APM-57 dated May 11, 1957 to all State Governments on protection of conditions of service post-reorganisation, protecting substantive pay etc. but no protection for departmental promotion, discipline, control etc.

Mysore General Services Revenue Subordinate Branch Recruitment Rules, 1959 made without previous approval of Central Government under s. 115(7) of State Reorganisation Act, varying conditions to petitioner's disadvantage.
Madras Government prior to November 1, 1956 reduced petitioner in rank in violation of Art. 311(2) and Art. 16.
State of Madras not made a party to the petition; petitioner never raised Art. 311(2) and Art. 16 points while serving under Madras.
All orders complained against by petitioner passed by competent authorities after considering merits.

legal_issues.text: Whether Mysore General Services Revenue Subordinate Branch Recruitment Rules, 1959 were made with previous approval of Central Government under s. 115(7) of State Reorganisation Act, and therefore do not govern petitioner insofar as conditions of service varied to his disadvantage.
Whether Madras Government prior to November 1, 1956 reduced petitioner in rank in violation of Art. 311(2) and Art. 16 of the Constitution.

petitioner_arguments.text: Mysore Rules 1959 not made with previous approval of Central Government under s. 115(7) States Reorganisation Act; GOI memo is not approval but abdication.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: s. 115(7) State Reorganisation Act; In re Bosworth; C. Appanna v. State of Mysore

petitioner_arguments.text: Madras Government reduced petitioner in rank prior to Nov 1, 1956 violating Art. 311(2) and Art. 16.

respondent_arguments.text: Petitioner considered from 1955 but not fit; promotion temporary; competent authorities judged merits; GOI memo permits changes in departmental promotion rules.
respondent_arguments.legal_basis: s. 115(7) State Reorganisation Act; GOI memo 11.5.1957

court_reasoning.text: Proviso to s. 115(7) preserves State power under Art. 309 but limits variation to disadvantage without previous approval of Central Govt; 'previous approval' includes general approval via GOI memo allowing changes in departmental promotion etc.; no need for scrutiny of minutest details; memo required sending copies for information.
court_reasoning.key_observation: GOI memo amounted to previous approval within proviso to s. 115(7)

court_reasoning.text: Procedural hurdles: State of Madras not party; points not raised earlier under Madras; difficult to quash orders affecting other servants; no showing of Art. 16 infringement; competent authorities judged merits.
court_reasoning.key_observation: No force in contention; no infringement of Art. 16 established

holdings.text: Mysore Rules 1959 validly made with previous approval via GOI memo.
No infringement of Art. 16 by Madras orders.

precedents_cited.case_name: In re Bosworth and Corporation of Gravesend
precedents_cited.relevance: Petitioner relied on as example of abdication but court finds no bearing on s.115(7) proviso

precedents_cited.case_name: C. Appanna v. State of Mysore
precedents_cited.citation: W.P. No. 88 of 1962, judgment dated January 13, 1964 (High Court of Mysore, unreported)
precedents_cited.relevance: Proceeded on concession by Govt Pleader; does not advance petitioner's case

statutes_cited.name: Constitution of India
statutes_cited.relevance: Petition under Art. 32 for enforcement of Arts. 14,16,19; violation alleged u/ Arts. 311(2),16; State power u/ Art. 309 subject to s.115(7)

statutes_cited.name: States Reorganisation Act, 1956
statutes_cited.relevance: Proviso requires previous approval of Central Govt for variation of conditions to disadvantage post-appointed day

statutes_cited.name: Madras State and Subordinate Service Rules

outcome.summary: Petition under Art. 32 dismissed as Rules 1959 validly made and no violation of Art. 16 established.

key_quotes.text: 'previous approval would include a general approval to the variation in the conditions of service within certain limits, indicated by the Union Government.'
key_quotes.speaker: court

key_quotes.text: The broad purpose underlying the proviso to s. 115(7) of the Act was to ensure that the conditions of service should not be changed except with the prior approval of the Central Government.
key_quotes.speaker: court

key_quotes.text: In our opinion, this amounted to previous approval within the proviso to s. 115(7).
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Holds GOI memo as sufficient approval
